question.title: ANR internal function on some devices

node.contents: What version of Android are those running? I'm having trouble lining up your stack trace with an implementation of SurfaceView -- onWindowVisibilityChanged is generally around line 200-230, not 329. e.g. https://android.googlesource.com/platform/frameworks/base/+/kitkat-release/core/java/android/view/SurfaceView.java

astNode.text: What version of Android are those running? I'm having trouble lining up your stack trace with an implementation of SurfaceView -- onWindowVisibilityChanged is generally around line 200-230, not 329. e.g. https://android.googlesource.com/platform/frameworks/base/+/kitkat-release/core/java/android/view/SurfaceView.java

node.contents: The stacktrace was from Android 4.2. But you're correct. The line numbers are somehow off. I just checked the other stacktraces but there all have the same numbers

astNode.text: The stacktrace was from Android 4.2. But you're correct. The line numbers are somehow off. I just checked the other stacktraces but there all have the same numbers

node.contents: The log seems to show your `BaseSurface.Update()` function trying to lock the canvas after the Surface was destroyed, which is at odds with the code (which appears to be joining the thread). If you use `logcat -v threadtime` you will get thread IDs in the logcat output, so you can see if the exception is being thrown on the same thread you just joined, or if a new thread was created.

astNode.text: The log seems to show your `BaseSurface.Update()` function trying to lock the canvas after the Surface was destroyed, which is at odds with the code (which appears to be joining the thread). If you use `logcat -v threadtime` you will get thread IDs in the logcat output, so you can see if the exception is being thrown on the same thread you just joined, or if a new thread was created.

node.contents: I've got a app which uses a surfaceview for displaying the UI. The app runs stable for about 18k users but there are 3 devices that get an ANR when returning to the surfaceview activity (sv activity->regular activity->back to sv activity).

astNode.text: I've got a app which uses a surfaceview for displaying the UI. The app runs stable for about 18k users but there are 3 devices that get an ANR when returning to the surfaceview activity (sv activity->regular activity->back to sv activity).

node.contents: The 3 devices are:

astNode.text: The 3 devices are:

node.contents:
• Onda Tablet (Allwinner A31 Chipset)
  • Sero 8 (Rockchip chipset)
  • Acer 10" Tablet with Intel Atom

astNode.text:
• Onda Tablet (Allwinner A31 Chipset)
  • Sero 8 (Rockchip chipset)
  • Acer 10" Tablet with Intel Atom

node.contents: I tried to recreate the ANR but failed. According to my users the app runs fine for hours without any problems except for the devices listed above.

astNode.text: I tried to recreate the ANR but failed. According to my users the app runs fine for hours without any problems except for the devices listed above.

node.contents: According to my interpretation the ANR occures before surfaceCreated gets called.

node.contents: I already searched a lot in the last days but didn't found any clue why this is happening. The only similar problem I found was here: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!msg/android-developers/0VuqnrYe7b0/Yw1mHodmrwoJ but he didn't posted any solution and his problem was not related to a specific device.

astNode.text: I already searched a lot in the last days but didn't found any clue why this is happening. The only similar problem I found was here: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!msg/android-developers/0VuqnrYe7b0/Yw1mHodmrwoJ but he didn't posted any solution and his problem was not related to a specific device.

node.contents: Did anyone else had these problems before with some specific devices and know a solution for this problem?

node.contents: Why does a exception get called? The draw thread is stopped before the surface is destroyed and nothing is touching the surfaceview anymore. Also why gets the surfaceCreated of the surface called after that exception? The activity is not even anymore visible at that point.

astNode.text: Why does a exception get called? The draw thread is stopped before the surface is destroyed and nothing is touching the surfaceview anymore. Also why gets the surfaceCreated of the surface called after that exception? The activity is not even anymore visible at that point.

node.contents: I also tried removing all synchronized blocks but they didn't changed the behavior.

astNode.text: I also tried removing all synchronized blocks but they didn't changed the behavior.

node.contents: I was just concerned that `Update()` could lock the canvas and then block trying to synchronize on `holder`.

astNode.text: I was just concerned that `Update()` could lock the canvas and then block trying to synchronize on `holder`.

node.contents: I found a way to randomly reproduce the ANR. It seems like the problem occures when closing the surfaceview activity (see new added stacktraces above).

astNode.text: I found a way to randomly reproduce the ANR. It seems like the problem occures when closing the surfaceview activity (see new added stacktraces above).

node.contents: Thanks for your response. It makes things clearer for me. What do you mean by "lock on SurfaceHolder before lockCanvas()"? The synchronizing blocks were only inserted to test if it's working with them but it seems like they don't do anything to the logic in my case

astNode.text: Thanks for your response. It makes things clearer for me. What do you mean by "lock on SurfaceHolder before lockCanvas()"? The synchronizing blocks were only inserted to test if it's working with them but it seems like they don't do anything to the logic in my case

node.contents: Looking at the ANR trace in the android-developers link, they're running Android 4.2 and their main thread is stalling when the SurfaceView tries to lock its Surface. I believe the problem there is that the render thread has called lockCanvas(), which locks the Surface (using a ReentrantLock), and then something happened that caused the SurfaceView to need to update (e.g. its size or position changed). You can see in the trace for the thread that (presumably) called lockCanvas() that it's actively running ("Thread-3899" is in NATIVE with state=R) in some complicated-looking bit of Skia code. So either the Skia code is looping forever, or is just taking a really long time to finish.

node.contents: In your case, the render thread (SurfaceDraw) is suspended, possibly because it finished what it was doing and was returning from native code to the VM. Yours was a simple drawARGB() call so I'm not sure why it would take so long. It's possible that something else stalled it, and this is just where it happened to be when the ANR snapshot mechanism finally caught up.

astNode.text: In your case, the render thread (SurfaceDraw) is suspended, possibly because it finished what it was doing and was returning from native code to the VM. Yours was a simple drawARGB() call so I'm not sure why it would take so long. It's possible that something else stalled it, and this is just where it happened to be when the ANR snapshot mechanism finally caught up.

node.contents: It might be wise to grab your lock on the SurfaceHolder before you call lockCanvas() to ensure that you don't block waiting for it with the Canvas lock held.

astNode.text: It might be wise to grab your lock on the SurfaceHolder before you call lockCanvas() to ensure that you don't block waiting for it with the Canvas lock held.

node.contents: (FWIW, synchronizing on a SurfaceHolder instance makes me a little nervous, since you can't know if something in SurfaceView is going to lock it for its own nefarious purposes. Don't think that's the problem here though.)
